presentations.title: ISP Network Architecture
presentations.description: A comprehensive technical deep-dive into Triple Play services, Access Networks, Fixed Core, and GPON technology.

sections.title: ISP Network Architecture
sections.subtitle: Technical Deep Dive
sections.content: Understanding the layered architecture of modern ISP networks: from fiber access to core routing, service delivery, and content optimization.

sections.title: Triple Play Service
sections.content: Triple Play represents the convergence of Internet, IPTV, and VoIP over a single broadband infrastructure. In modern GPON-based networks, this convergence is achieved by logical separation rather than physical segregation.

items.title: Internet Traffic (VLAN 100)
items.description: Best-effort unicast traffic for web browsing, downloads, and general connectivity.

items.title: IPTV Traffic (VLAN 200)
items.description: Multicast for live TV channels, unicast for on-demand video (VOD) content.

items.title: VoIP Traffic (VLAN 300)
items.description: Low-latency, real-time unicast streams requiring priority QoS treatment.

sections.title: Traffic Routing in Triple Play
sections.content: Internet and VoIP traffic routes through BRAS for subscriber authentication and policy enforcement, while IPTV traffic bypasses BRAS and reaches the SPINE switch directly. QoS is enforced end-to-end, ensuring VoIP and IPTV maintain priority during high Internet usage.

items.title: ONT
items.description: Handles VLAN tagging at customer premises, separating Triple Play services at ingress.

items.title: OLT
items.description: Performs traffic shaping, multicast replication for IPTV, and upstream scheduling.

items.title: BRAS
items.description: Manages subscriber authentication, IP policy enforcement, and AAA accounting.

sections.title: Access Network
sections.content: The Access Network is the 'last mile' connecting subscriber devices to the ISP's infrastructure. In GPON deployments, it encompasses all physical media and devices from the customer premises up to the Optical Line Terminal (OLT) at the provider's access point. It handles traffic encapsulation, VLAN tagging, and QoS marking but does not perform IP routing or authentication.

items.title: Copper (DSL)
items.description: Legacy technology using telephone lines for broadband. Limited speeds, still common in older deployments.

items.title: Coaxial (HFC)
items.description: Hybrid Fiber-Coax: fiber to neighborhood nodes, then coax to homes. Uses DOCSIS modems for cable TV ISPs.

items.title: Fiber Optic (GPON)
items.description: Glass/plastic fiber transmitting light pulses. Fastest, most future-proof with minimal interference and extremely high bandwidth.

sections.title: Home Gateway
sections.content: A home gateway (residential gateway) is a consumer device combining modem/ONT (physical link to ISP), router (manages LAN), Wi-Fi access point, firewall, NAT, and DHCP. It's the demarcation point between the customer's network and the ISP's access network. This single device handles VLAN tagging for Triple Play services before forwarding to ONT.

items.title: Modem
items.description: Converts ISP medium signals (copper, coax, fiber) into Ethernet packets. DSL modem for phone lines, cable modem for coax.

items.title: Router
items.description: Takes network connection and shares it with multiple devices. Provides routing, NAT, firewall, and LAN management.

items.title: Gateway
items.description: Combines modem + router + Wi-Fi in a single ISP-provided unit. Most common in modern GPON deployments.

items.title: ONT
items.description: Optical Network Terminal: converts fiber light signals into Ethernet for use by local devices.

items.title: CPE/Home Gateway
items.description: Customer premises equipment providing WiFi, routing, VLAN tagging, and service demarcation.

items.title: ONT/MDU
items.description: Optical Network Terminal converting fiber signals to Ethernet for the subscriber.

items.title: Optical Splitter
items.description: Passive device splitting one fiber into 1:32 or 1:64 subscriber connections without power.

items.title: OLT
items.description: Optical Line Terminal at central office managing all ONTs in the PON tree.

items.title: Metro Cluster
items.description: Active-Standby aggregation switches providing redundancy and uplink diversity.

sections.title: Wi-Fi in Access Networks
sections.content: Wi-Fi is not part of the ISP access network itself‚Äîit's the last local access technology inside customer premises, bridging user devices to the home gateway. However, Wi-Fi performance directly impacts perceived ISP service quality, which is why ISPs standardize on newer Wi-Fi versions like Wi-Fi 6.

items.title: 1. Scanning
items.description: Client sends probe requests to detect available networks (SSIDs). Access Points reply with probe responses.

items.title: 2. Authentication
items.description: Client and AP exchange management frames. This is wireless link security (WPA2/WPA3), not internet login.

items.title: 3. Association
items.description: Client sends association request; if accepted, becomes part of the Basic Service Set (BSS) and can exchange data.

items.title: 4. Secure Handshake
items.description: WPA2/WPA3 4-way handshake to derive encryption keys and establish secure connection.

items.title: 5. IP Assignment
items.description: After association, client obtains IP via DHCP. Only then can traffic flow to the ISP access network.

items.title: Wi-Fi 4 (802.11n) - 2009
items.description: Introduced MIMO. 2.4/5 GHz bands. Up to 600 Mbps. First 'modern' Wi-Fi, still in legacy devices.

items.title: Wi-Fi 5 (802.11ac) - 2014
items.description: 5 GHz only. Up to 6.9 Gbps. MU-MIMO. High throughput but struggles with many devices.

items.title: Wi-Fi 6 (802.11ax) - 2019
items.description: 2.4/5 GHz. Up to 9.6 Gbps. OFDMA, TWT, 1024-QAM. Designed for high-density environments.

items.title: Wi-Fi 6E - 2020
items.description: Same as Wi-Fi 6 but extends into 6 GHz band. More capacity, less interference. Adoption varies by country.

items.title: Wi-Fi 7 (802.11be) - 2024+
items.description: Multi-Link Operation across 2.4/5/6 GHz. Up to ~46 Gbps. Designed for AR/VR and ultra-low latency.

items.title: OFDMA
items.description: Splits channels into smaller resource units to serve multiple devices simultaneously.

items.title: MU-MIMO
items.description: Multi-user parallel transmissions for better handling of many connected devices.

items.title: Target Wake Time
items.description: Schedules device wake times to save battery power on IoT and mobile devices.

items.title: Better Latency
items.description: Lower contention and airtime efficiency‚Äîideal for IPTV, VoIP, and gaming.

sections.title: Wi-Fi 6 and GPON Symmetry
sections.content: Both Wi-Fi 6 and GPON rely on centralized scheduling: Wi-Fi uses OFDMA (AP schedules airtime), while GPON uses TDMA (OLT schedules bandwidth). This architectural symmetry makes Wi-Fi 6 a conceptual match for fiber access networks, both handling shared medium access with QoS-aware design.

sections.title: High Availability in Access
sections.content: The access network ensures reliability using Active-Standby Metro clusters and redundant OLT uplinks. IPTV multicast replication and VoIP QoS tagging are handled at this layer. Most subscriber-level outages occur here: ONT failures, fiber cuts, or local power issues. Metro switch and OLT uplink failures are mitigated by HA mechanisms.

sections.title: Fixed Core Network
sections.content: The Fixed Core Network is the high-capacity IP/MPLS backbone of a telecommunications provider. It interconnects access networks (GPON, DSL, Metro) with service platforms (Internet, IPTV, VoIP) and external networks, providing routing, transport, policy, and interconnection. It is technology-agnostic regarding access but service-centric and IP/MPLS-centric in design.

sections.title: Access vs Core: The Hard Boundary
sections.content: The core network never touches physical last-mile media‚Äîit operates purely at Layer 3 and above (with MPLS between L2‚ÄìL3). While the access network handles last-mile aggregation and is subscriber-unaware (dealing with physical access, GPON/OLT, and VLANs), the core network provides centralized backbone services and is subscriber-aware via BRAS, handling logical services through IP and MPLS routing with policy enforcement.

items.title: Service Edge (BRAS/BNG)
items.description: Subscriber session termination, authentication, IP assignment, policy enforcement, and QoS marking at the boundary between access and core.

items.title: Core Routing (HCORE)
items.description: High-capacity stateless packet forwarding using MPLS and IP routing. No subscriber logic‚Äîpure speed and reliability.

items.title: Service Interconnect (SIG)
items.description: Traffic steering, policy-based routing, and interconnection to service platforms like CDN, DNS, and IPTV middleware.

items.title: Internet Gateway (IGW)
items.description: Exit point to global Internet with BGP peering to upstream providers and IXPs like MIX.

items.title: External Networks
items.description: Public Internet, Internet Exchanges, CDN origins, and inter-carrier connections.

sections.title: Service Edge: BRAS / BNG
sections.content: The BRAS (Broadband Remote Access Server) or BNG (Broadband Network Gateway) is the first true core element‚Äîthe boundary between access and core. It terminates subscriber sessions (PPPoE or IPoE), interacts with DHCP/RADIUS for IP assignment and AAA, enforces subscriber policies, applies QoS marking and traffic shaping. After BRAS processing, traffic becomes pure IP/MPLS.

items.title: PPPoE / IPoE
items.description: Subscriber session protocols for authentication and connection establishment.

items.title: DHCP Relay
items.description: Relays IP address requests to DHCP servers for dynamic assignment.

items.title: RADIUS AAA
items.description: Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting for subscriber management.

items.title: QoS / DSCP
items.description: Traffic classification, CoS marking, and shaping per-subscriber policy.

items.title: VLAN / Q-in-Q
items.description: Handles VLAN tags from access network and strips/translates them.

items.title: ACLs
items.description: Access control lists for security and traffic filtering.

sections.title: HCORE: High-Capacity Core Routing
sections.content: The HCORE is the heart of the fixed core network. Its only job is to move packets fast, reliably, and redundantly across the ISP backbone. It features extremely high throughput (100G/400G ports), low latency, no subscriber logic, and stateless forwarding. Technologies include IP routing (IPv4/IPv6), MPLS (LDP/RSVP-TE/SR-MPLS), ECMP load balancing, and Fast Reroute (FRR) for sub-50ms recovery.

items.title: IP Routing
items.description: IPv4 and IPv6 routing for packet forwarding across the backbone.

items.title: MPLS
items.description: Label switching for traffic engineering, service separation, and L2/L3 VPNs (LDP, SR-MPLS).

items.title: IGP (IS-IS/OSPF)
items.description: Interior gateway protocols for internal topology discovery and convergence.

items.title: BGP
items.description: Border Gateway Protocol for service routing and external peering.

items.title: ECMP
items.description: Equal-Cost Multi-Path for load balancing across parallel links.

items.title: Fast Reroute
items.description: MPLS FRR for sub-50ms failover upon link or node failure.

sections.title: SIG: Service Interconnection Gateway
sections.content: The SIG layer connects core routing to service platforms. It provides service separation, traffic steering, and policy-based routing to interconnect with CDN, DNS, IPTV middleware, and VoIP softswitches. SIG acts as a controlled fan-out point‚ÄîDNS queries route to DNS servers, CDN traffic to HCDN, and Internet traffic to IGW.

sections.title: IGW: Internet Gateway
sections.content: The Internet Gateway is the exit point from the ISP's network to the global Internet. It handles eBGP peering with upstream providers, BGP peering with IXPs (like MIX), route filtering and policies, traffic engineering via local preference and AS-path prepending, NAT (when needed), and DDoS protection. In your network: SIG ‚Üí IGW ‚Üí Public Internet, and SIG ‚Üí MIX.

items.title: Private IPs (RFC1918)
items.description: Assigned at BRAS, used between subscriber and BRAS. Requires CGNAT at SIG/IGW for Internet access.

items.title: Public IPs
items.description: Assigned directly at BRAS for enterprise or premium subscribers with direct Internet routing.

items.title: Core Infrastructure
items.description: Core routers, HCORE, SIG, and IGW use public IP addressing for routing and peering.

items.title: No Single Point of Failure
items.description: All critical components deployed in pairs with active-active or active-standby configurations.

items.title: ECMP Load Balancing
items.description: Traffic distributed across multiple equal-cost paths for bandwidth and resilience.

items.title: MPLS Fast Reroute
items.description: Pre-computed backup paths enable sub-50ms convergence upon failure.

items.title: BGP Fast Failover
items.description: BFD-triggered BGP session teardown for rapid peering convergence.

items.title: Stateful Switchover
items.description: SSO maintains session state during control plane switchover on redundant routers.

items.title: Access Link Failure
items.description: Single subscriber isolated. No impact to core network.

items.title: Metro Switch Failure
items.description: Limited regional impact. Traffic reroutes via redundant metro pair.

items.title: BRAS Failure
items.description: Session drop for affected subscribers. Standby BRAS takes over.

items.title: Core Link Failure
items.description: Traffic rerouted via MPLS FRR. Invisible to subscribers with <50ms convergence.

items.title: IGW Failure
items.description: Traffic rerouted to alternate exit. BGP reconverges to backup peering.

items.title: Internet
items.description: Unicast routing through BRAS ‚Üí HCORE ‚Üí SIG ‚Üí IGW with best-effort QoS.

items.title: IPTV
items.description: Multicast routing via PIM/IGMP. QoS priority for jitter-sensitive video streams.

items.title: VoIP
items.description: Low-latency routing with strict QoS. DSCP marking preserved end-to-end.

items.title: CDN Integration
items.description: HCDN for local traffic offload, reducing transit costs and latency.

items.title: MTU Consistency
items.description: Uniform MTU (typically 9000 for jumbo frames) across all core links to prevent fragmentation.

items.title: MPLS Label Stack
items.description: Proper label depth management for VPN and traffic engineering tunnels.

items.title: Route Reflectors
items.description: Strategic BGP RR placement to scale iBGP without full mesh.

items.title: Control Plane Protection
items.description: CoPP policies to protect routers from DoS attacks on management/control plane.

items.title: Clock Synchronization
items.description: PTP/NTP for time-sensitive protocols and logging correlation.

sections.title: GPON Technology
sections.content: GPON (Gigabit Passive Optical Network) is the access technology backbone for modern fiber broadband. It multiplexes multiple subscribers over a single fiber using Time-Division Multiple Access (TDMA) for upstream and broadcast for downstream.

items.title: ONT Identification
items.description: Each ONT is identified by serial and port ID, authenticated via OLT using PLOAM messages.

items.title: Downstream Encryption
items.description: Traffic is encrypted per ONT using AES-128, ensuring subscriber privacy on shared fiber.

items.title: Bandwidth Allocation
items.description: Deterministic bandwidth per subscriber through T-CONT and Dynamic Bandwidth Allocation (DBA).

items.title: Multicast Efficiency
items.description: IPTV multicast streams are replicated efficiently at the OLT, reducing upstream bandwidth.

sections.title: GPON Scalability
sections.content: GPON enables the access network to scale to thousands of subscribers while preserving QoS and HA. Service separation (Internet, IPTV, VoIP) occurs at the physical layer with VLAN-based isolation. Unicast VOD flows are forwarded to SPINE switches while multicast is replicated at OLT level.

sections.title: Unified Architecture View
sections.content: Together, Triple Play, Access Network, Fixed Core, and GPON form a layered architecture that delivers reliable, scalable, and differentiated services to subscribers.

items.title: Layer 1: GPON
items.description: Fiber-based physical foundation connecting subscriber premises to metro aggregation.

items.title: Layer 2: Access Network
items.description: ONTs, splitters, OLTs, and metro clusters ensuring HA and proper service separation.

items.title: Layer 3: Fixed Core
items.description: Subscriber logic, routing, policy enforcement, NAT, and content optimization.

items.title: Layer 4: Triple Play Services
items.description: Internet, IPTV, and VoIP delivered over these layers with VLANs and QoS ensuring coexistence.

sections.title: Unified Analysis Capability
sections.content: Understanding these four components together allows you to analyze packet flows, failure points, IP mapping, multicast delivery, and redundancy mechanisms. This knowledge is essential for troubleshooting, capacity planning, and network optimization in ISP environments.
